heading.title: PART 4 PREPARATION AND FILING OF DOCUMENTS [rr 4.1–4.16]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 4 PREPARATION AND FILING OF DOCUMENTS [rr 4.1–4.16]

entry.emph: Division 1 — Preparation of documents generally — Rules 4.1–4.9

row.entry: These rules in this Division prescribe the physical appearance, formal title and contents of documents. They require specific information to be included in originating process. They require parties to have an appropriate address for service and regulate the procedure for changing addresses for service.
This Division contains provisions relating to the procedure for filing documents in court. It permits the court to strike out, or remove from the court file, scandalous and irrelevant material.

This Part applies to all courts in CPA Sch 1: see UCPR r 1.5 and Sch 1 . This part (other than rr 4.2 , 4.9 and 4.12 ) applies to the criminal proceedings in the Third Schedule to the Supreme Court Act: see SCR Pt 75 r 3 .

These rules have substantially the same effect as the provisions of former rules relating to the contents and filing of documents for use in proceedings. The former Rules from which the present provisions derive, include SCR Pts 1, 9, 38 and 65; DCR Pts 8 and 47; LCR Pts 7, 25 and 36. The present rules contain some changes of detail related to the requirements of an Electronic Case Management system of the kind contemplated by UCPR Pt 3 .
Case number or other unique identifier to be assignedto originating process ‥ [r 4.11]
Delegation by NSW Trustee and GuardianDocuments — required format ‥ [r 4.3]
Lodgment of additional copies of originating process for service ‥ [r 4.12]
Service at a document exchange box ‥ [4.5.5]
Subrogation — information required when corporation conducts proceedings ‥ [r 4.16]

p.text: This Division applies to and in respect of any document that is prepared by or on behalf of a person (whether or not a party) for use in proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 4.2] r 4.2 Documents to be filed to contain certain information (cf SCR Part 1, rule 10, Part 7, rule 2, Part 11, rule 4, Part 65, rule 1; DCR Part 5, rule 2; LCR Part 36, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Documents to be filed to contain certain information (cf SCR Part 1, rule 10, Part 7, rule 2, Part 11, rule 4, Part 65, rule 1; DCR Part 5, rule 2; LCR Part 36, rule 7)

p.text: Originating process filed on behalf of a party in any proceedings must contain the following information:
the name of the court in which the proceedings are to be commenced,
if relevant, the division in which the proceedings are intended to be heard,
if relevant, the list in which the proceedings are intended to be entered,
the venue at which the proceedings are intended to be heard,
the title of the proceedings,
the nature of the process (summons or statement of claim),
if the party has engaged a solicitor to act as the party’s legal representative, the name of the solicitor,
if the process is filed by a person who is neither the party nor the party’s solicitor or solicitor’s agent, the capacity in which the person acts when filing the document,
the party’s address and the party’s address for service,
the address, if known, of any defendant.
A solicitor named on the originating process pursuant to paragraph (e1) is thereby the solicitor on the record in relation to the party on whose behalf the process is filed.

[subr (1) am Amendment 4 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[1] and [2], effective 11 November 2005 ; Amendment 10 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 7 July 2006 ; Amendment 23 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 7 November 2008 ; Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 6 March 2009]
A document filed on behalf of a person in relation to any proceedings (other than originating process) must contain the following information:
the title of the proceedings, as appearing on the originating process for the proceedings,
if relevant, the division in which the proceedings are intended to be heard,
if relevant, the list in which the proceedings are intended to be entered,
the case number for the proceedings, as appearing on the originating process for the proceedings,
the nature of the document,
if the person has engaged a solicitor to act as the person’s legal representative, the name of the solicitor,
if the document is filed by a person who is neither a party nor a party’s solicitor or solicitor’s agent, the capacity in which the person acts when filing the document,
[repealed]
In relation to paragraph (c), see rule 9.1(4) and (5) which require cross-claims to be numbered.
A solicitor named in the document pursuant to paragraph (d1) is thereby the solicitor on the record in relation to the party on whose behalf the document is filed.

[subr (2) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[1]-[3], effective 15 August 2005 ; Amendment 10 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 7 July 2006; Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[1], effective 7 December 2007 ; Amendment 23 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 7 November 2008 ; Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 6 March 2009]
A notice to be filed under Division 9 of Part 78 of the Supreme Court Rules 1970, or a caveat to be filed under Division 10 of that Part, must contain the following information:
if the notice or caveat relates to proceedings already commenced:
the title of the proceedings, as appearing on the originating process for the proceedings, and
if relevant, the division in which the proceedings are intended to be heard, and
if relevant, the list in which the proceedings are intended to be entered,
the case number or unique identifier assigned to the notice or caveat under rule 64 or 73 of that Part, as the case may be,
the nature of the document,
if the person has engaged a solicitor to act as the person’s legal representative, the name of the solicitor,
if the notice or caveat is filed by a person who is neither a party nor a party’s solicitor or solicitor’s agent, the capacity in which the person acts when filing the notice or caveat.
[subr (2A) insrt Amendment 56 of 2012 Sch 1[1], effective 21 January 2013]
The originating process and any such document may also contain the
DX address, fax number or electronic mail address of the person, the person’s solicitor or the person’s solicitor’s agent.
[subr (3) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[4], effective 15 August 2005]

Court documentation within the meaning of section 347 (Restrictions on commencing proceedings without reasonable prospects of success) of the Legal Profession Act 2004 that is not required by that section to be certified must include a statement to the effect that it is not required to be so certified.
[subr (3A) insrt Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[2], effective 7 December 2007]
Subrule (3A) does not apply to documents that are filed in the Land and Environment Court in relation to proceedings in Class 1, 2 or 3 of that Court’s jurisdiction.
[subr (3B) insrt Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 8 August 2008]
In this rule, originating process does not include any process (such as a statement of cross-claim or cross-summons) by which a cross-claim is made.
[subr (4) insrt Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 30 September 2005]

In exceptional cases the court may permit proceedings to be commenced without the disclosure of the plaintiff's name: DM v TD (NSWSC, Cole J, 4 February 1994, unreported, BC9402267) (AIDS victim suing a doctor in relation to the contraction of AIDS following a medical procedure): see the Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 especially ss 7 and 8.
Legislation cited in [4.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 17.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 50.

CPA s 17 permits the Uniform Rules Committee to approve forms for documents to be used in connection with civil proceedings subject to the CPA and UCPR. The approved forms are set out in Volume 3 behind the guide card “Forms”. The following forms provide a general form of document that should be used where no more specific form has been approved:
Form 81 (for Pt 50 appeals)
Form 101 (for Court of Appeal).
In any proceedings in which there are more than 2 plaintiffs, or more than 2 defendants, the plaintiff must file, together with the originating process, a list of parties.

In any proceedings in which there is a cross-claim brought by more than 2 cross-claimants, or to which there are more than 2 cross-defendants, or against a cross-defendant who is not already a party to the proceedings, the cross-claimant must file with the statement of cross-claim or cross-summons:
if no list of parties has yet been filed in the proceedings, a list of parties, or
if a list of parties has already been filed in the proceedings, an amended list of parties.

In any proceedings in which a list of parties has been filed, any party who files a document that effects a change of parties (including a change that involves the addition of a party who is not already a party to the proceedings) must file, together with the document, an amended list of parties.
[r 4.2A subst Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 6 March 2009]
Legislation cited in [4.2A.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 50.
The approved forms for list of parties are Form 2 , Form 82 ( Pt 50 appeals), Form 102 (Court of Appeal).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 4.3] r 4.3 Paper and writing (cf SCR Part 65, rule 2; DCR Part 47, rule 3; LCR Part 36, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Paper and writing (cf SCR Part 65, rule 2; DCR Part 47, rule 3; LCR Part 36, rule 4)

p.text: A document must be on standard A4 paper of durable quality, capable of receiving ink writing.
Subject to the rules:
a document may be one-sided (that is, with writing on one side of each sheet) or two-sided (that is, with writing on both sides of each sheet), but not partly one-sided and partly two-sided, and
the sheets of a document must be securely fastened:
if the document is one-sided, at the top left hand corner, or
it the document is two-sided, along the left hand side, without obscuring the writing or the margin, and
a left margin of at least 25 millimetres, and a top margin of 30 millimetres, must be kept clear on each sheet of a document that bears writing, and
the pages of a document (that is, the sides of the sheets that bear writing) must be consecutively numbered.
[subr (2) am Amendment 4 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 11 November 2005]
The spacing between the lines of writing in a document must be at least 3 millimetres.
The following information in a document must be set out in bold:
the name of the first plaintiff and first defendant in the title of the proceedings,
in the case of a cross-claim, the name of the first cross-claimant and first cross-defendant in the title to the proceedings,
in the case of a notice of motion, the name of the person affected by the orders sought,
in all cases, the name of the person specified in the filing details as the person for whom the document is filed.
[subr (3A) insrt Amendment 6 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[1] , effective 9 December 2005; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[4], [5], effective 7 December 2007]
A document must bear writing that is clear, sharp, legible and permanent, must not be a carbon copy and must not bear any blotting, erasure or alteration that causes material disfigurement.
This rule does not apply to a document to the extent to which the nature of the document renders compliance impracticable.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 4.4] r 4.4 Signing documents (cf SCR Part 65, rule 8, Part 66, rule 9; DCR Part 47, rule 5; LCR Part 36, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Signing documents (cf SCR Part 65, rule 8, Part 66, rule 9; DCR Part 47, rule 5; LCR Part 36, rule 6)

p.text: If, in any proceedings, a document is required to be signed by a party:
in the case of a party who is represented by a solicitor, the document may not be signed by the party but must instead be signed:
by the party’s solicitor, or
by a solicitor acting as agent for the party’s solicitor, or
by some other solicitor belonging to or employed by the same firm or organisation as the party’s solicitor or party’s solicitor’s agent, and

in the case of a party who is not represented by a solicitor, the document may be signed by the party and may also be signed by any other person who is authorised by these rules to commence proceedings on the party’s behalf.
[subr (1) subst Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[5] effective 30 September 2005; am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 8 December 2006]
Subrule (1) is subject to the requirements of rule 35.3 .
[subr (2) subst Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[5] effective 30 September 2005]
Despite subrule (1), a document prepared on behalf of a party in proceedings in the Local Court may instead be signed:
by a commercial agent with respect to debt collection (within the meaning of the Commercial Agents and Private Inquiry Agents Act 2004), in relation only to proceedings on an application for:
an instalment order, or
an order for examination, or
a writ of execution, or
a garnishee order, or

by a person holding a licence as a real estate agent, strata managing agent or on-site residential property manager within the meaning of the Property, Stock and Business Agents Act 2002 in relation only to:
proceedings on an application referred to in paragraph (a), or
the filing of a certificate under section 51 of the Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001.

[subr (3) am Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[6] effective 30 September 2005 ; Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 9 June 2006 ; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
Despite subrule (1) , a document setting out proposed consent orders between the parties to the relevant proceedings may instead be signed on behalf of a party by the party's barrister.
[subr (4) insrt SI 462 of 2012 r 3, effective 14 September 2012]
Legislation cited in [4.4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 3.3, 3.4A, r 4.4(1)(b), 4.4(3).

A person who is authorised by UCPR r 4.4(1)(b) or 4.4(3) to sign documents on behalf of a party in Local Court proceedings may be registered as a user of the ECM system and may e-file documents: UCPR rr 3.3 and 3.4A .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 4.5] r 4.5 Address for service (cf SCR Part 9, rule 6; DCR Part 8, rule 8; LCR Part 7, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Address for service (cf SCR Part 9, rule 6; DCR Part 8, rule 8; LCR Part 7, rule 8)

p.text: Subject to subrule (2), a person’s address for service is to be the address of a place in New South Wales (other than a DX address):
at which documents in the proceedings may be left for the person during ordinary business hours, and
to which documents in the proceedings may be posted for the person.
The address for service of a person who has a solicitor on the record is to be:
the office of the solicitor on the record, or
if the solicitor on the record has another solicitor acting as agent, the office of the agent.
[subr (2) subst Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 6 March 2009]
Despite subrules (1) and (2):

the address for service of a defendant who is served with originating process outside New South Wales, but in Australia, may be any address in Australia, whether inside or outside New South Wales, and

the address for service of a person who files a notice under section 19(1) of the Mutual Recognition Act 1992 of the Commonwealth (other than a person who is represented by a solicitor) may be any address in Australia, whether inside or outside New South Wales, and

the address for service contained in an application to set aside a subpoena made under section 13 of the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 of the Commonwealth (other than a person who is represented by a solicitor) may be:
any address in Australia, whether inside or outside New South Wales, or
any address in New Zealand, and

the address for service of a person who has entered an appearance under the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 of the Commonwealth is to be the address for service stated in relation to the appearance.

level.toc-caption: [4.5.5] Service at a document exchange box

p.text: Legislation cited in [4.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.5(2)(a).

heading.title: Service at a document exchange box

p.text: This rule, when read with r 10.5(2)(a) of the UCPR, has the effect that documents (other than originating process) may be served by delivery to the document exchange box of the solicitor representing the party to be served, or by delivery to the document exchange box of that solicitor’s agent.

It is implicit in the rule that a post office box is not a proper address for service: Sarikaya v Victorian Workcover Authority (1997) 80 FCR 262; [1997] FCA 1372; BC9706553 ; Hanna v Registrar of the Court of Appeal of NSW [2006] NSWSC 564; BC200604590 at [10] . Kelly v Mosman Municipal Council (2010) 178 LGERA 136; [2010] NSWCA 370; BC201009839 at [64] and following (post office box is not a place and therefore cannot be an address for service).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 4.6] r 4.6 Changing address for service (cf SCR Part 9, rule 6; DCR Part 8, rule 8; LCR Part 7, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Changing address for service (cf SCR Part 9, rule 6; DCR Part 8, rule 8; LCR Part 7, rule 8)

p.text: A person may change his or her address for service by filing a notice of the change showing his or her new address for service and serving the notice on all other active parties.
[subr (2) rep Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[6], effective 7 December 2007]
The approved form is Form 76 : Notice of change of address for service.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 4.7] r 4.7 Numbers (cf SCR Part 65, rule 4; DCR Part 47, rule 4; LCR Part 36, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Numbers (cf SCR Part 65, rule 4; DCR Part 47, rule 4; LCR Part 36, rule 5)

p.text: All dates, sums and other numbers in a document are to be expressed in figures, rather than words.
Despite subrule (1):
months may be expressed in words, rather than numbers, and
if dates are expressed wholly in numbers, they must be expressed in the form DD/MM/YY or DD/MM/YYYY.
Unless the court otherwise orders, in any claim or judgment for the possession of land, and in any writ of execution in relation to land, the description of the land must include:
a formal description of the land sufficient to identify the land in any document establishing title to the land, together with any appropriate reference to title, and
the postal address (if any) of the land.
Without limitation, a formal description of land referred to in subrule (1)(a) may be given:

in the case of land under the provisions of the Real Property Act 1900 that comprises the whole of the land referred to in one or more folios of the register under that Act, by reference to the relevant folio identifiers, or
in the case of any land (including land referred to in paragraph (a)), by reference to:
[r 4.7A insrt Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 8 December 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 4.8] r 4.8 Separate documents for separate process

p.text: Separate process (such as a defence and a statement of cross-claim or a cross-summons, or a reply and a defence to a statement of cross-claim) are to be dealt with in separate documents.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 4.9] r 4.9 Delegation by NSW Trustee and Guardian (cf SCR Part 63, rule 16)

leg:heading.title: Delegation by NSW Trustee and Guardian (cf SCR Part 63, rule 16)

p.text: If, in connection with any proceedings involving a person under legal incapacity, a delegate under section 9 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 signs a document in the exercise of a function delegated under that section, the delegate must include in the document a statement:
of the delegate’s name and position, and
that the document is signed in exercise of a function delegated under that section, and
if the delegate has not previously signed such a document in the proceedings, as to whether or not he or she has an interest in the proceedings adverse to that of the person under legal incapacity.
[subr (1) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[1], effective 8 October 2009]

On request by the court, the registrar or any party to the proceedings, the delegate must furnish to the person making the request a photocopy of the delegation, certified by the delegate as being a true copy.
